div1.p:
In the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington Northern Division.
Judgement Roll No. 275
Ex parte - M. L. Coovert on Habeas Corpus Plaintiff vs. Defendant Register No. Filed June 22nd 1893
A. Reeves Ayres Clerk.
R. M. Hopkins Deputy Clerk.

In the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington
Northern Division.
June Term, 1893
Be it Remembered, That on the 12th day of June 1893 there was duly filed in said Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington, Northern Division, a petition for writ of habeas corpus and two appearances in words and figures as follows, to-wit:

No. 1 To the Honorable Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington:
Ex parte M.L. Coovert Your petitioner M.L. Coovert complains and shows to the court as follows: That he is a citizen and resident of the State of Washington, and that he is unjustly and unlawfully detailed and imprisoned by George Nerton by the order of and upon a warrant issues by the Honorable E. A. Wiswall, sitting and acting as judge of the Superior Court of the State of Washington for the County of Clarke, a copy of which warrant is hereto attached marked "Exhibit No. 1," and which your petitioner prays may be considered as a part of this petition, the same as if it was expressly incorporated in it. And he ever since has been kept in confinement and under arrest, and now is under arrest as aforesaid and restrained of his liberty upon the following charged: Violation of the following law of the State of Washington:
"Section 1. That it shall be unlawful for any person or persons whatever to manufacture, buy, sell, give, or furnish to any one cigarettes, cigarette paper, or cigarette wrapper. "Sec. 2. That whosoever manufactures, buys, sells, gives or furnishes to any person or persons cigarettes, cigarette paper or cigarette wrapper shall be feemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not more than $500 or imprisoned in jail not exceeding six months, or both, for each offense. "Sec. 3 This act shall be liberally construed to the end that its object shall be enforced. "Sec. 4. All laws or parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this act are hereby repealed." And upon the informationaffidavit of which a copy is hereto attached, and marked as "Exhibit No. 2," and which your petitioner expressly makes a part of this petition, the same as if incorporated in it, and prays that it may be so considered. And that immediately upon the arrest of your petitioner, he was taken before the said Honorable E.A. Wiswall, sitting and acting as judge of the Superior Court as aforesaid, and as a committing magistrate. That before said magistrate testimony was given by C. L. MacDonald and G. A. Stapleton as follows: that your petitioner had sold to C. L. MacDonald a package of cigarettes, marked "Vanity Fair" being ten paper-wrapped cigarettes, enclosed in a pasteboard slide box having upon it the name of the manufacturer _ Brand of Cigarettes number of Manufacturing District and State and number of cigarettes.

with the caution notice required by the laws of the United States printed on the side of said Coy, and the United States internal revenue stamp for ten cigarettes pasted across the end of said box so as to act as a seal. And the said package so sold by your petitioner was produced before the committing magistrate as evidence, and is herewith produced as "Exhibit No. 3" of this petition.
The aforesaid facts your petitioner admits to be true. The said cigarettes were sold in Oregon to your petitioner by the American Tobacco Company, doing business in the state of New York and said cigarettes were manufactured in New York, and were not shipped to your petitioner in pasteboard bozed, containing similar such packages, exactly similar to said "Exhibit 3." That said pasteboard boxes are called "cartons" by the trade, and are used simply for the purpose of making convenient parcels of the packages of cigarettes for enumeration and handling at the factory, and to protect the cigarette packages when in storage, and one of such "cartons" is herewith produced as "Exhibit No. 4" of this petition, and is more particularly described as follows:
